articles.headline: From New Deal to New Hard Times, Eleanor Endures
articles.snippet: For the town of Eleanor, which took its name from the first lady of the New Deal, government action still works.
articles.abstract: For the town of Eleanor, which took its name from the first lady of the New Deal, government action still works.

articles.headline: Wall Street, the Depression and the Lords of Finance
articles.snippet: These six books — about financial history and how economics went astray — are informative and enjoyable.
articles.abstract: These six books — about financial history and how economics went astray — are informative and enjoyable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Crisis brings out the best in some people, or so it is said. It certainly produced some excellent books this year.

articles.headline: Rise of Wind Turbines Is a Boon for Rope Workers
articles.snippet: A growing number of people who enjoy rock climbing are finding work inspecting, cleaning and repairing wind turbines.
articles.abstract: A growing number of people who enjoy rock climbing are finding work inspecting, cleaning and repairing wind turbines.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAHANOY TOWNSHIP, Pa.  Suspended by ropes from the top of a giant wind turbine, two men slowly descended down a long, silvery blade. Then they got to work, and from 150 feet above the ground, the hum of a sander filled the air.

articles.headline: New Film Ignites Debate on Ratings Policy
articles.snippet: The film “It’s Complicated” received an R rating for a scene in which two stars share a joint, kicking up attacks on the M.P.A.A. for being out of touch.
articles.abstract: The film “It’s Complicated” received an R rating for a scene in which two stars share a joint, kicking up attacks on the M.P.A.A. for being out of touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The romantic comedy “It’s Complicated” arrived at the multiplex on Friday complete with an R rating, ranking it in the same category as “The Texas Chainsaw Massacre” and “Basic Instinct” in the eyes of the Motion Picture Association of America.

articles.headline: Hard-Line Rise Alters View of Iran’s Nuclear Ambition
articles.snippet: Political turmoil has made it nearly impossible for anyone in Iran to support nuclear cooperation without being accused of capitulating to the West.
articles.abstract: Political turmoil has made it nearly impossible for anyone in Iran to support nuclear cooperation without being accused of capitulating to the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Until Iran’s current political crisis, Iranian experts largely agreed that the Islamic republic wanted to develop the capacity to build nuclear weapons, without actually producing them.

articles.headline: Health Care Changes Wouldn’t Have Big Effect for Many
articles.snippet: For the roughly 160 million people who get insurance through an employer, the result of the long, angry health care debate may be just more of the same.
articles.abstract: For the roughly 160 million people who get insurance through an employer, the result of the long, angry health care debate may be just more of the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that the Senate has caught up with the House by passing a sweeping health care bill, lawmakers are on the verge of extending coverage to the tens of millions of Americans who have no health insurance.

articles.headline: Where There’s Smoke ... There’s a Trade-In
articles.snippet: As temperatures drop, efforts to curb pollution from burning wood are clashing with tradition.
articles.abstract: As temperatures drop, efforts to curb pollution from burning wood are clashing with tradition.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H.  The wood stove was blazing in Rosemary Urato’s living room on Christmas Eve, giving off a hypnotic glow and only a hint of smoky smell. It is brand new and cleaner than its predecessor, which was dispatched to a scrapyard last month.

articles.headline: At Fort Hood, Reaching Out to Soldiers at Risk
articles.snippet: After the Nov. 5 shootings, the post is trying to show that it can care for its frailest and most battle-weary soldiers.
articles.abstract: After the Nov. 5 shootings, the post is trying to show that it can care for its frailest and most battle-weary soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT HOOD, Tex.  The day after a gunman killed 13 people here last month, Lt. Gen. Robert W. Cone, the post’s commander, fired off an e-mail message to an unusual audience: local advocates for disaffected soldiers, deserters and war resisters. “I am told you may be able to help me understand where some of the gaps are in our system,” he wrote.

articles.headline: Doing Good by Paying Forward
articles.snippet: Microfinancing is becoming a popular way of donating to nonprofits by giving or lending money through an online marketplace of sorts.
articles.abstract: Microfinancing is becoming a popular way of donating to nonprofits by giving or lending money through an online marketplace of sorts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the next few days, as you tuck your holiday gifts away, your thoughts may turn to paying some of your good fortune forward.
